metadata.sermon_title: A Question Out Of The Darkness
metadata.notes: The sermon addresses the psychological state of doubt and suffering, using the historical figure of John the Baptist as a proxy for the listener's internal struggle.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. The sermon is remarkably low on 'musts' and 'shoulds'. It validates doubt rather than shaming it.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids the traditional CP role of condemning doubt. Instead of 'You must believe,' the preacher suggests 'A person can lose one's faith... if he is not careful,' which is more of a cautionary Adult observation than a CP command.
quotes: Nor does it matter how bitter the complaint!
If it is honest, be confident that God will accept whatever it is we truly have to lift up

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. The preacher acts as a supportive companion in suffering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong but not infantilizing. It provides a 'holding space' for the listener's 'quiet desperation' without offering a cheap, smothering fix.
quotes: He knoweth our frame and remembereth that we are dust.
Night after night you stare into the darkness and stifle a sob...

adult.score_explanation: 10 = Strong Adult presence. The preacher uses historical context and reality-testing.
adult.analysis: The preacher invites the listener to process data: 'Tell him to make his decision upon the basis of my record.' This is an invitation for the listener's Adult to evaluate evidence rather than just obey.
quotes: Look around now and you will see, I think, in your life signs that God is at work, though not as you requested.
If a man doubts God's judgment, let him look first at history...

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. The sermon encourages moving away from the 'good boy/girl' compliance toward honesty.
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher explicitly gives permission to stop being an 'Adapted Child' who hides feelings, encouraging the expression of 'bitter, angry complaint.'
quotes: At first he would smother the thought in his mind, ashamed of it.
There will be other days when we can only muster a bitter, angry complaint.

free_child_FC.score_explanation: 10 = Authentic, playful, joyful. The sermon is somber, but contains authentic emotional expression.
free_child_FC.analysis: The Free Child is present in the vivid, sensory descriptions of John (locusts, wild honey, ablaze eyes) and the validation of 'glad laughter.'
quotes: deep and glad laughter of joy

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as one who has also struggled ('My grip nearly slipped'), establishing a horizontal Adult-Adult connection rather than a vertical Parent-Child one.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Minimal. The social message (it's okay to doubt) matches the psychological message (I accept you in your weakness).
transaction_analysis.purity_explanation: 10 = Completely transparent. The preacher is honest about the lack of easy answers.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only risk is a slight 'Bait & Switch' where the pain of the listener is used to pivot to a traditional hymn, but it feels more like a resource than a trap.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon avoids 'ITHY' (I'm Only Trying To Help You) by refusing to provide a simplistic solution that would eventually fail. By validating the 'darkness' as a reality that may not change immediately, the preacher avoids the 'Switch' to Persecutor when the listener doesn't 'get better' instantly.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. The preacher does not promise to fix the listener's life, but to accompany them.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Absent. There is no blaming of the listener for their lack of faith.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. The preacher shares a moment of vulnerability ('grip nearly slipped') but does not stay in the Victim role to garner pity.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited out of the 'Victim' role (helplessness) into an 'Adult' role (evaluating the evidence of God's presence).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Yes. The sermon offers 'Autonomy' by validating the listener's right to their own feelings and honest complaints.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically robust and exceptionally healthy. It avoids the common homiletical trap of the Critical Parent (shaming the doubter) and the Rescuer (promising miracles that don't come). By speaking from an Adult/Nurturing Parent position, the preacher fosters a sense of 'I'm OK, You're OK' even in the midst of suffering. It validates the 'Free Child's' right to scream or complain, which prevents the 'Adapted Child' from forming a resentment-filled, fake faith.
strengths: Validation of negative emotions as 'honest' and 'acceptable'.
Use of Adult-level reality testing (looking at history and personal record).
Avoidance of 'NIGYSOB' by not hunting for sins to explain the listener's suffering.
areas_for_improvement: The transition to the hymn 'All the way my Savior leads me' could be perceived as a slight 'smothering' NP move that closes the tension too quickly.
More 'Free Child' spontaneity could balance the heavy somberness of the text.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to use 'we' and 'I' to maintain the Adult-Adult horizontal plane. Ensure that when offering 'signs of God' (Adult data), you remain open to the listener's Adult concluding that those signs are currently insufficient for them.
